'''Fell beasts''' and '''fell creatures''' were vague terms used to describe different monstrous, evil, and dangerous [[Kelvar|animals]] and other [[creatures]] that existed in [[Middle-earth]] (but not in [[Aman]])<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.05.020}}</ref> from the [[Elder Days]] until the late [[Third Age]]. The [[Nazgûl-birds|winged steeds]] of the [[Nazgûl]]<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.031}}</ref>,<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.042}}</ref> in addition to [[Werewolves]],<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.19.011}}</ref> were described as fell beasts. The Nazgûl themselves<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=UT 3.04.01.004}}</ref> and [[hill-trolls]]<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.10.057}}</ref> were sometimes called fell creatures. In some cases [[Orcs]], [[Trolls]], and [[Dragons]] were distinguished from fell beasts.<ref name=":0">{{Cite DTP|id=S RP.043}}</ref>

== History ==
When the [[Spring of Arda]] was marred, some beasts became monstrous creatures with horns and tusks.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.01.007}}</ref> In [[Utumno]], [[Morgoth|Melkor]] bred monsters of different shapes and kinds.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.03.002}}</ref> At these times, [[Oromë]] came to Middle-earth as a hunter of monsters and fell creatures<ref name=":1">{{Cite DTP|id=S VQ.02.013}}</ref>.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.01.020}}</ref>

While Melkor was [[Chaining of Melkor|captured]] by the [[Valar]], not all of his evil creatures were destroyed. They multiplied in the darkness, and even before the return of Morgoth, fell beasts of the North were roaming far and wide in the lands east of the [[Blue Mountains]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.10.008}}</ref> so the [[Nandor]] who inhabited woods of [[Eriador]] were frightened<ref name=":3">{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.10.012}}</ref> and fled from the plains to the hills<ref name=":2" /> or migrated to [[Ossiriand]].<ref name=":3" /> Soon fell creatures came even to [[Beleriand]] over passes in the mountains and from the [[Taur-im-Duinath|dark forests]] of the south.<ref name=":4">{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.10.009}}</ref> When Morgoth returned, he gathered countless hosts of beasts, [[demons]], and Orcs in [[Angband]],<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.09.019}}</ref> while the wilderness of [[Nan Dungortheb]] was inhabited by fell creatures of [[Ungoliant]]<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.16.006}}</ref> including [[spiders]] and other monsters.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.19.013}}</ref>

Fell beasts continued to trouble Middle-earth during the [[Second Age]] and the Third Age.<ref name=":0" /> In the Third Age, many fell beasts and evil creatures began hunting in the [[Mirkwood|Greenwood]] when the forest became haunted by darkness.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S RP.044}}</ref> The [[Witch-king]] gathered many fell creatures as well as Orcs and evil [[Men]] in his realm of [[Angmar]] in order to destroy the [[Dúnedain of Arnor]].<ref name=appendixa>{{App|Eriador}}, entry about King Malvegil, p. 1040</ref> The [[Dúnedain of the South|Dúnedain]] of [[Gondor]] also faced threats from monsters in addition to Orcs and evil Men.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S RP.037}}</ref> During the [[War of the Ring]], [[Frodo Baggins]] had a vision at the [[Seat of Seeing]] atop [[Amon Hen]] wherein he saw [[Wood-elves]] and [[Woodmen]] [[battle under the trees|battling]] against fell beasts in Mirkwood.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 2.10.054}}</ref>

== Etymology ==
In relation to the expression "fell things" in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'',<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 1.03.178}}</ref> ''[https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fell#Etymology_4 fell]'' means "dreadful, terrible, fierce, cruel" as an archaic English word.

== Similar terms ==
'''Monsters''',<ref name=":1" /> '''fell beings'''<ref name=":4" />, '''foul creatures'''<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 4.10.040}}</ref> and '''evil creatures'''<ref name=":1" /> were similarly vague and perhaps even more broad terms. Both monstrous spiders<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.09.018}}</ref> and Orcs<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 6.06.048}}</ref> were sometimes called "foul creatures"<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=UT 3.01.00.013}}</ref>. [[Oliphaunts]] were sometimes called "monsters"<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.071}}</ref> and "great monsters"<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 5.06.053}}</ref> as well as occasionally "[[great beasts]]".

'''Beasts of [[Angband]]''' was a term to describe all beasts in the hosts of Morgoth,<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.20.018}}</ref> such as [[wolves]] and maybe Dragons as well.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S QS.20.016}}</ref>

'''Misshapen beasts''', alongside demons, Dragons, and Orcs, were among evil things devised by Morgoth in the days of his dominion that continued to trouble [[Men]] during the [[Dark Years]] of the Second Age.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=S AK.003}}</ref>

'''[[Magic|Spell]]-enslaved beasts''', alongside Orcs, Trolls, [[Easterlings]], and [[Haradrim]], were a part of [[Sauron]]'s army in the [[Battle of the Morannon]]<ref>''[[The Chronology of The Lord of the Rings]]'', V. A Published Chronology: Appendix B, 1. "Here at the end of all things", pp. 149 (entry for March 25 in Table 14 ''continued'')</ref>.<ref>{{Cite DTP|id=LR 6.04.009}}</ref> The exact nature of these beasts is unknown.
